last_replies.com: Someone in one of the Turn threads mentioned that Tomino was offered episodes for Reco but turned it down because he was worried about his age. Not too unsurprising given how hands on he was with it but I do wonder if having more time might have helped the reception. Maybe not a full 50 maybe a nice 36.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21342884
It wouldn't have helped anything. Even in 2014 the audience wasn't able to pay attention to anything unless there were long expositions with every character waiting and taking turns speaking. We've gotten to the point where MGS1 dialogue is unironically what people expect.
Tomino shows can have tons of dialogue, then have no dialogue and nothing but visual storytelling, then ramp right back into nonstop chatter where characters don't speak in a constructed manner made for the audience to know everything.
However, he's also not vague so you can't have lorefags the same way the Soulsborne franchise has gotten where they pretty much just write fanfiction in the absence of explicit messaging.
G-Witch thinks the audience is retarded, and they are, and the characters present themselves in overly dramatic turn taking so the audience latched on to it. You'll never get something like Zeta Gundam or Turn-A where 5 conversations are happening at once on screen, over comms, and in a battle all about different subjects and the cast itself getting confused about what's going on because that requires an audience pays attention to who is fighting who, where everyone is, and what different people are talking about. Kamille tracking an Asshimar that betrayed the Titans to protect the city while Char is giving his speech while Amuro is doing other shit is information overload for the modern audience.

>>21342810
In Ichijo's case, the alternative is to willfully orchestrate violence and inspire the masses to unilaterally slaughter everyone she considers evil, not because they necessarily pose a continued threat to the innocent, but because she's so dedicated to an extreme Kantian retributive justice that justice itself is synonymous with killing. I'm not saying I think that there are absolutely no situations in which lethal force can be justified, but I think the novel makes an interesting point about the nature of killing, and since it found the argument the novel makes thought-provoking, I like it even if I don't necessarily agree with it.

>>21342816
According to the novel, the point of the Law is to discourage the use of lethal force on the whole, recognizing that whomever you might seek to destroy is more than the label of "guilty" you attach to them, and that killing them deprives the world of the good they could potentially become had you chosen another path. Muramasa is loathed because weapons and violence SHOULD be loathed as instruments of murder, which is inherently unjustifiable. My issue is that the characters in Muramasa don't really alter their behavior in light of that; maybe this is different in other routes, but in the Ichijo route they just continue on the warpath as before, apparently deciding it's okay because now they're willing to acknowledge that they shouldn't be doing what they're doing. It's one thing to say that taking a life is a serious act that should never be taken lightly; it's another to say "yes, killing is completely unjustifiable under any circumstances, but I'm going to make a career out of it anyway."

***READ THE GUIDE***

THE GUIDE: http://gunpla.buyfags.moe/

***READ THE GUIDE***

For those new to gunpla/plamo or even just new to this thread; please read the guide. Please read it before asking questions, as there is a chance it has already been answered there.

For those unfamiliar, "plamo" is a shortened form of "plastic model". If it's made of plastic, someone can probably help you here!
If you're new, you're gonna fuck up. Don't worry! If you're experienced, don't make the new people worry!

And remember to report any shitposting and spam to keep the thread clean and civil.

>Why won't anyone answer my question?
Try being specific, especially about your materials and process. Post images whenever possible; even if the kit/part looks bad, you are more likely to get help posting images.

>Why are my pictures sideways?
4chan strips EXIF data from images when they're uploaded to the site from your phone, including the orientation display tag. To fix this, save your images separately, or use an app that will rotate and save the images for you.
One commonly used app that works well on Android:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.simplemobilephotoresizer

I still don't know where people calling me a boomer comes from and I don't hold anything against my generation and I have friends my age and all that I just acknowledge that I'm a weird outlier and so speak with a halfway in the door perspective.
Also thing on the topic at hand it really does come down to the main entry process being "hey kids look at these cool robots fight each other" and then hit them with the deeper shit that keeps them in from there.
Which doesn't work anymore people see war as bullshit and all of the aspirational jobs and the culture that drove people towards grand futurist fantasies has been replayed with you either wanting to be an influencer or coming to terms with a job where you settle early on.
The Yuri on the other hand taps into a live wire of current social interest across the board.
But there needs to be an onboard process from that point, and while I personally don't like it more Yuri based shows and an acceptance of Yuri based community seems to be how we get people "in" for the here and now.
If this isn't the future wanted than the only solution is to hope the companies don't feed into it and to wait for a more favorable moment to build on.
In other words for the time being Yuri will be the future of Mecha.

last_replies.com: Sazabi is so ass and melts from everything. what is he even supposed to do??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21342554
Close ranged shotgunner with a shield
Sazabi works well when protecting poi and its weakness is being ganged up on or a melee unit, without the shield its extremely squishy
You can use the boost ability to catch up to a teammate or quickly get to where your axe was thrown, along the way if an enemy is in your path you'll also damage them, so if you miss an axe throw you can boost up to the axe and possibly hit the enemy with your boost tackle while also closing distance to get better damage on your shotgun
It can also see a targeted enemy with its lock-on ability so if the enemy leaves your eyesight you can still track the general area, spot an enemy and if they try to surprise attack around a corner you're well aware
Stick close with the team and use your thrusters to get closer to the enemy in small spaces
Use the axe throw to stun an enemy or knock down their shield, save it for when you run into an enemy GM or Sazabi or Gundam, you can also test your luck and throw it at transforming or flying MS, if you manage to hit a Turn A using its G-Maneuver special or a Methuss flying in the air with the axe it will stop them, its a game changer if you can properly aim it
The G-Maneuver is pretty ass imo, the Funnels are good for targeting one enemy, while it can hit all enemies in the area, the more enemies the less damage it does, with one enemy the funnels will focus all the damage on a single target but with multiple enemies the damage is spread out so you won't end up getting any kills

Practice the Sazabi in Casual, once you get the hang of it then use it in ranked, its a valuable teammate in the right hands

>>21339385
Here you go, anon. Very unrefined sketches. Like I said I'm more of a writer than an artist. The idea is that there is a mass-produced "modern" sleek design (which is the one on the right as an example, I tried to make the head look "round" and friendly while still being somewhat cool, but I'm not sure on it) and then the important characters have customized versions of it, (like the example in the bottom middle). The "transformation" doesn't make much sense, I was gonna go over the logistics of it with the artist friend. I had read that underwater the things that dictate speed is how round something is and how long it is, which is why submarines are pill shaped, that's why I thought of making the legs slim and long.

Worth noting that I've avoided seeing Mars Daybreak on purpose but I've caught glances at the main mech occasionally and I know it also has long legs. I know the design on the right is extremely simplistic but I thought it would be best to figure out a "template" (aka the mass-produced version) before designing the custom ones (and even then I still came up with the skeleton one).

My idea is that they'd move around by bursting in straight lines and wide curves whilst putting their slim bodies facing forward (like a diver or like in the transformation draft) and then have gas canisters that can just, boost from the joints to make sharp corrections or turns (but doing them too much wastes gas of course). They'd be equipped with large weapons they'd carry like Patlabor and utilities like wire cannons on the hips to grab onto opponents or sea structures.

com:
I'm releasing an update to the Gihren's Greed translation as an early Christmas present. This release translates the rest of the main AEUG campaign meaning at this point more than half of the game is translated. All that's left are the main Titans and Axis campaigns and the small extra campaigns.

This release took longer than expected since it turns out the AEUG campaign actually has more dialogue in it than either the Federation or Zeon campaigns which took me by surprise. Next on the list I'll be doing the extra campaigns since those are all just intro, an event, and endings so they can all be translated quickly. After that, it will be the main Titans and Axis campaigns which are both shorter than any of the campaigns translated so far.

For those who aren't familiar with this translation the main Federation, Zeon, and AEUG campaigns and the majority of the UI are all translated. The only things I have left to translate are the remaining campaign dialogue and some UI elements. You'll need to use my custom version of the PPSSPP emulator included with the translation to play it as I use its texture replacement feature for most of the translation.

Also included are my character mods which include 52 character variations and new characters that were mainly made just for fun and to help with Copy X's runs there are instructions inside on how to enable and disable them.

If you want to support the translation you can either donate to me through PayPal, upload save states for untranslated events, or translate events yourself and add them to my translation document, any of these are appreciated.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>21335310
Gainax: TTGL is probably their most celebratory show, while Eva is the most technically impressive one. TTGL (and Diebuster to the same extent) felt like a logical continuation of the themes depicted in Gunbuster. Art style and animation quality is the only thing it got over these two.
Their best show is secretly Nadia. Shame they won't re-release the Nautilus cut. FLCL, Wings of Honneamaise and Kare Kano are also pretty good, though I wouldn't describe them as /m/ shows, even if the first two have some overlapping appeal.
Trigger: Their best show in terms of overall quality is Little Witch Academia, but it's not /m/, nor is KLK. I thought that Franxx was shit and didn't enjoy Promare, Gridman and Dynazenon that much, so I'll go with Edgerunners, since I found it to be tolerable.

There's the GuAIZ R, but the existing features of the previous machines would lead to cool stuff if allowed to further develop, especially if they still did the mission packs like the ZAKU did.
>hip railguns being standard would have given ZAFT one hell of a firepower advantage over the EA's forces.
>sword on the GINN could be made as a mass-produced anti-ship sword for instance, being part of a melee-specialised package paired with the cable knives a la Sword Impulse.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21338848
>hip railguns being standard would have given ZAFT one hell of a firepower advantage over the EA's forces.
Annoyingly, railguns are low-grade peasant weapons in the CE universe. They're often depicted as being clunky ineffective weapons. As part of the ZAKU's development history, there's a prototype ZAKU equipped with hip railguns but it was dropped for the final design.

>GuAIZ's beam claw shield might have evolved to a regular shield with beam saber mounting, such that it could be used as a beam claw like the GuAIZ and also allow for the beam sabers to be drawn and used normally.
This is more or less already a thing on the GuAIZ R, databook writeups say that the twin beam claws were replaced with a beam sabre. We never see the sabre detached from the shield and used standalone, but that might be a consequence of it being considered an "obsolete" MS that isn't given much screentime in the show. In any case the beam sabre isn't molded directly into the shield and the shield tip design even looks like a socket and has a noticeable seam, so in all likelihood the beam sabre is detachable from the shield, but we never have any footage or concept art of it doing that.

>>21328385
Sky Girls and SW both have character designs by Humikane Shimada, the "mecha musume" guy. Neither is a knockoff of the other.
SW ended up getting a lot of sequels while Sky Girls never saw any continuation, though at 26 episodes it has more than the first two seasons of SW combined.
The two shows are very different despite sharing some aesthetics and a conflict with monsters. Sky Girls has revealing pilot suits but only light fanservice. The cast is a balanced mix of girls and guys, with almost every girl having a male love interest. SW has more, and more perverted, fanservice, it tries to appeal to militaryfags with the girls being based on historical figures, and the cast is almost entirely female with no romance allowed beyond yuribait.

name: Anonymous
com:
Do you lads see Zambot 3 as a "true classic" or is it mostly a historical piece?
I lean more towards the latter. It has its moments (Killer the Butcher, human bomb arc, last 4 eps) but alot of the other episodes can be pretty anemic, especially during the first 9 episodes when the production staff were still trying to find their groove and the interesting/memorable elements hadn’t really kicked in. They also struggled making good robot fights, even the latter half had a few duds.

Definitely got the feeling that most of the buzz around this series comes down to it being interesting to look back upon (Sunrise’s first original, defined Tomino's career path, pulls a couple of genre conventions on their head), rather than being a well-made show in it’s own right.
”Impact over quality” is not a problem I have with ’70s anime as a whole, if anything there are quite a few that still stand strong on their own merits and aren’t as wooden in terms of direction (staging, lighting, editing/pacing, use of music, etc.).
>Yamato and Harlock blend fantastical space adventures with heavy subject matter in a very appealing way, with some great music and cinematic direction to boot (especially in Harlock), and the characters ain’t too shabby either. These two really feel like the pure platonic ideal of a space opera come to life, the greybeards who see them as ”the greatest TV cartoons ever made” ain’t too far off.
>Mazinger Z has alot of fun character interactions and devious ”master plans” to go with the iconic monsters
>Danguard Ace is a heartfelt father and son story, and the giant robot stuff doesn't disappoint either (have only seen the 2013 compilation films though)
>First Gundam did a good job in terms of forward momentum, while keeping the characters and battles interesting even during the less eventful episodes
All in all I wouldn’t say I’ve been ”cheated” of my time for watching Zambot, I’m just curious about it’s following.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21329399
I like Daitarn but it is an extremely different show from Zambot, basically on the opposite end of the Tomino spectrum (where one end is depressing tragedy and the other is lighthearted romps). Daitarn 3 is a MotW comedy where the protagonist spends about half the show as a spy outside the robot, with silly fourth wall breaks and Star Wars references by which I mean ripoffs. It gets a bit serious a few times but it's overall what I'd call a great palette cleanser after Zambot 3's sad ending
